page.title: 02St.Paul de Lyon,Staverton
page.content: The Anglo-Saxons probably built a small church here, but a small red sandstone arch in the west wall of the vicarage garden is all that is visible evidence of the Norman building.The present building was begun in 1304 at the command of the Bishop of Exeter. In 1610 Bishop Stapledon caused the additions to be made to make the fine towered edifice it is today.The most interesting parts of our church are the Rood Screen that was madein the 15th century and restored in 1891 in beautifully carved oak,and the bells first hung in the 1550's.The clock is worked by weights which have to be wound up each week with a big handle.There is also a rare parvise over the porch, a kind of room where visiting clergy could stay.We have also 'rubbed' the monumental brass on the outside of the chancel wall.
